titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Estus H. Magoon photographs FA088

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2015-10-25 05:52:43 -0400.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Materials requiring specialized equipment for access (film, audio, video, slides) may be closed to research dependent on availability of the applicable equipment
Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be closed to researchers at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services/Head of Reference.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Estus H. Magoon was born in 1882, and graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). A sanitary engineer, during World War I he served with the American Red Cross in Albania and Serbia. At the conclusion of the war, he joined the staff of the International Health Division and for thirty-eight years made over three hundred trips to twenty-five Latin American countries bringing clean water supplies as a result of his efforts. Mr. Magoon retired from the Foundation in 1957.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Important subjects in this collection include World War I in Albania and malaria control in Greece, Albania, Costa Rica, British Honduras, and Brazil.

4. Durazzo, Albania, 1916. Serbians and Romanian gypsy near an old wall. 5. Durazzo, Albania, 1916. Native Albanians. Serbians are seated. 6. Durazzo, Albania, 1916. Street scene in the business district. 7. Durazzo, Albania, 1915. Serbian soldiers in retreat. 11. Costa Rica, 1929. Construction of reinforced slab of concrete for sanitary privy. Mold was made in Costa Rica and sent to other Central American countries. Metal molds were made in Venezuela for the same purpose. 12. Tres Rios, Costa Rica. Completed sanitary privy. 13. San Lucas, penal colony island of Costa Rica. Anopheles control measures. Background: shallow water tank used for curing cement sand tiles. Foreground: machine used to form the tiles before they are placed on the shelves. 14. San Antonio, British Honduras. Indian home. 15. Belize, British Honduras. Mahogany logs being towed up Haulover Creek to sawmill at Belize. 16. Nearly identical image of #15.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Estus H. Magoon deposited his photographs with the Rockefeller Foundation Archives in 1963.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: RAC is unable to provide access to obsolete media and original digital media. In addition separated media may not yet have undergone stabilization procedures. When feasible, a digital surrogate may be created via special order. All applicable charges will apply. See RAC Head of Archival Services or RAC Head of Digital Programs for details.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the userâ€™s responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.
